all_paragraphs: American whistle-blower Edward Snowden, and former National Security Agency (NSA) Director Michael Hayden have said that America is more secure and safer with “unbreakable end to end encryption.” Snowden continues that “I can promise you … one thing: If I am standing shoulder to shoulder with the director of the National Security Agency on something, there’s a damn good reason for that.”

Anyone working with data has a responsibility to make sure that sensitive data is not at-risk from being stolen. Too often the implemented cybersecurity policies are followed as a check list of bare minimums, and this as it turns out, isn’t enough. In 2018 T-Mobile, Quora, Facebook, and 18 other major companies succumbed to data breaches. Unfortunately, data ethics and data security are often overlooked. Take this post as a quick tutorial on encrypting your own data, and please further educate yourself on how to properly implement encryption on database systems.

The idea of encryption is simple: data can be scrambled by a sender with an encryption key, and then unlocked by the receiver with a decryption key. Symmetric encryption means that the encryption key and decryption key are the same. This is the less effective method as the delivery of the key could be intercepted digitally. Asymmetric encryption means that the encryption key and decryption key differ. Asymmetric encryption, or public-key encryption, is accomplished with the use of a public key and a private key. The private key is used to decrypt the data.

Good encryption keys should be no smaller than 2048 bits. Keys larger than this are rarely used because of the significant computational burden; however, a key this size is good enough as it would take a normal computer 14 billions years to crack a 2048-bit certificate, and nobody has got time for that.

Mr. Therriault noted that there is no excuse not to encrypt your data. It is on your device, and therefore it is your responsibility to encrypt the data you use, especially if you are working with sensitive data. I currently have a database with my friend’s names, social security numbers, and a list of their worst fears. If anyone got this information, it could spell danger!

Now you should have three files. The original file, an encrypted version of that file, and a decrypted version of that file. As long as you have the key, you may delete the original file and only keep the encrypted version. Proper key management is critical to the effectiveness of encryption. Keys should always be kept in a separate and secure place. You shouldn’t keep your encryption keys within a file or in the same folder. This would be the same as keeping your key to your front door underneath your doormat.

You can even encrypt your encryption key! This is known as a Key Encryption Key (KEK), which should be isolated from the data it unlocks. The best practice would involve securing your KEKs with a Master Encryption Key and a Master Signing Key. Using different keys for different parts of data is also a good practice. This may be difficult because it requires the user to know which key to fetch every time the data is encrypted or decrypted. It is possible to decrease your chances of getting hacked by following proper encryption protocol, but unfortunately the majority of programmers do the bare minimum when it comes to data security. Too many developers follow a checklist mandated by guidelines like HIPAA or company policy, but these guidelines are usually not enough for a proper defense against data breaches. With great power comes great responsibility, and if you are working with sensitive data on your computer it is your responsibility to protect that data. Educating yourself on the details of encryption and the best methods of implementation should prevent a data breach from happening to you. Practice encrypting your files because you never know who could be looking.
